author: dragoaus
body:
In personal opinion, one of the major drawbacks is, that management can "juice" its salary and bonus by doing repurchases, since by doing repurchases, they increase the stock price (usually metric on which their Bonus is calculated).

Second major issue is that repurchases of stock robs company of valuable capital, that could have been invested in upgrading production process and R&D. This specially hurts manufacturing and R&D heavy companies. 
For example from 1995 through 2019 IBM spent $201 billion buying back its own stock. 
At one point, management of IBM was bragging, how R&D expenditure of IBM has been reduced, so he could have more profits and returns to shareholders (dividends and repurchases). This worked great in short run, but results are clearly visible now, IBM is shadow of itself, company that was leading Innovation for decades is now a service company. 
Management got its bonuses, shareholders enjoyed short-term gains, but in the end where left with shell of company.
This was not only reason for IBM issues, but contributed significantly.
For more recent example, check Boing and Intel, both wasted fortunes on buybacks. Both were cheered by Wall Street for it, but in reality, both companies underinvested in their future.
I am not against buybacks, only it needs to clear, there is no free lunch, especially not in R&D heavy Industries.

author: falconne
body:
If a big energy company was able to drive the cost of renewables down so much it crashes the green tech companies, then they wouldn't need to buy them out, discount or not, since that implies the big company has leapfrogged them in tech.

Thing is, innovation and engineering is hard. You can't solve every problem by throwing money at it. If you're coming in to a field 10 or 20 years behind in research, just being big doesn't mean you're going to catch up in tech just like that. Look at what happened to IBM in the face of upstarts like Microsoft, Google, Amazon, etc.

Even if big companies can fund their own research later, that will put them a decade or more behind. Meanwhile, another big energy competitor could buy up several successful startups and quickly become the dominant player. So like with tech startups, the big players won't be looking for discounts, they'll just wait to see who makes the best proven breakthroughs and then compete with each other to acquire the best tech first.

author: exe_virus
body:
Big tech will be regulated to hell. Maybe not now, not in 5 years. But it will be anti monopoly regulated until a new crop emerges and overtakes. 

Happened with AT&T bell in the 60's which led to IBM, AMD, Texas instruments, etc.

Then in the 80's/90's, antitrust threats is what led these large hardware companies to outsource their software OS to Microsoft and apple and Unix. 

Then in the 2000's we had Microsoft Monopoly broken up and the dot com crash, which led to Google, myspace, etc. Then in '08 google and Qualcomm and all these technologies came together to form what allowed today's JavaScript web based companies like Facebook, YouTube (google), linkedin (Microsoft) you get the idea. 

What has allowed big tech to stay on top is *acquisitions*. When that power is taken away, you will see big tech's investment thesis fall apart. And lo and behold that's the kind of anti monopoly regulations we are starting to see.

author: OrangeDutchy
body:
The private space sector is just getting started. It's such a young company ,14years so it doesn't even have a driver's license. Speaking of which consider Ford going public in '56, look at all those decades of building up before going public. Or IBM over 100 years ago. 

So profitability, being so young its all about scaling up and expanding their facilities. Any money is being used to make them more competitive. They believe they can do that by building a larger rocket which will broaden their capabilities. They will be receiving a 750million dollar cash injection. 200 of which will be going to designing and building the next rocket [Neutron ](https://youtu.be/agqxJw5ISdk). Give them room to screw up and lets put it at 250. The rest of the money could go to a number of things. Building a launch pad in New Zealand for Neutron, they have a deal to use the existing launch pad in Wallops, Virginia. They could build three more Neutron rockets, you could have a fleet. Cycling one out and brining in a new improved model throughout the years. They also have their own unique satellite bus built in-house, [Photon](https://youtu.be/LAUj-TQpn-A). First it delivers the payload of other satellites, but it's also open to configuration. I hope they have plans on scaling that up for the Neutron.  They are currently generating revenue, but no they are not cash flow positive, they hope to reach  that in a couple years.

Sustainable, as a private company they made it through the global recession of 08(I know that's a weak point). Their still acquiring more partners as they continue to develop their product. For instance BlackSky started by launching their prototype with another launch provider, but now they have multiple launches contracted with Rocketlab. 
This is still a young industry, if the speculation about mining in space comes true, I believe they will be well positioned for that market. In the mean time it's all about satellites. I think we're at a crossroads, the infrastructure on a large scale could be changed. Do we continue laying and maintaining ground lines to connect everyone on the network? Or do we launch a bunch of satellites and change so everyone goes back to putting a dish on their roof? Or Winnebago, and have internet in the middle of nowhere?

Scaleable, I've already hinted towards scalability with a fleet of larger rockets. Possibly larger satellite busses. But it's space, so I want you to use your imagination and think if it's scalable.

author: SirGlass
body:
Yes historically I could see a reason to collect dividends trading fees were high, some brokerages charged extra fees for odd lots some only sold lots of 100 at a time.

So if you had stashed away 100k in IBM stock in the 1990s collecting $500 in dividends every quarter was free. You could get a check mailed to you. Selling $500 of stock every quarter would cost you $35-60 in trading fees what is like 10% fees. Collecting a dividend was a free way to sell and bi-pass trading fees.

Now the fees are so low or almost nonexistent the benefit of selling is you have the choice when/how much to sell. A dividend is a forced taxable event

TSMC supplies Apple, NVDA, Intel, AMD, Samsung, Qualcomm, IBM, Microsoft, Sony etcetcetcetc. They are responsible for over 70% of the words chips. Sure, we're investing in US production of chips but TSMC is strategic by keeping their most important/advanced nodes on mainland Taiwan.  

China wants Taiwan. USA and allies will back Taiwan because it's a matter of national security and it's in our best interest to not get fucked by China.  

You're right, TSMC the company is not monetarily 'worth' 5 Trillion right now. But what's the price tag of a country that 70% of the worlds chips rely on? What are the collective value of lives that will be lost over that war? It's worth more than 5T in my books.

author: FinndBors
body:
> This ain’t like 2000

In a ton of valuation metrics they are worse than any other time in history other than 2000. And when people think of 2000, they think of pets.com being ridiculous. Those shit companies were not in any index and pets.com was 300-400 million market cap at its peak (which it held for a very short time). You can equate pets.com to companies like NKLA which make gravity powered trucks. NKLA was ~ 30B market cap at its peak -- and it's still worth 5B+. Pets.com actually had a business / revenue, tons of SPACs are little more than post series A companies, all of them worth well over a billion.

The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

The only thing that is legitimately different now than before is low interest rates. Which is why inflation / fed reaction is a genuine serious fear.

author: Mr_Dude12
body: I’m predicting that Tesla may be in for haircut once the everyone else starts to roll out their own electric cars. I cannot dismiss the ingenuity they have used to make a golf cart a true luxury car. Their weakness is business model, repairability is a nightmare, selling cars without key features then making by them subscription items? They are not cars, they are hardware with software licenses that are only profitable if you count the pollution credits sold.  Established carmakers won’t play these games, will have local service departments and build them to be a hat they are: cars. They have been doing it for a century. The chip shortages have made them focus on high end models, I kinda doubt they will start the base model production given the profitable high end models will bring. I see the brands that you know selling higher end, and coach built super high end cars. Once the patents begins to expire, we will see Chinese cars flood the low end with of the shelf tech. I am in on Nio and researching the Chinese makes that are actually producing and selling cars today. I liken it to the IBM computer “clones” of the ‘80’s. We will see compatible plug and play parts. Anyone research the scooter market? China has super factories that you can order any number of scooters, at any price point based on the quality of the parts specified, then slap your model name in them. ( check out AliBaba.com, buy a shipment, print your labels and poof, you are a scooter manufacturer). Trademarks? Pfft. We will see a flood of odd names sold over the internet just like you buy your Dell or off brand computers. Money will be in batteries, mining for rare earth metals, etc.

author: kfuzion
body:
Short answer, yes that would work. But chasing stocks with high dividend yield is usually a bad idea. It can work sometimes, of course. But I'd strongly suggest looking at the holdings; oil companies, AT&T, IBM, lots of riffraff has high dividends but they could easily have low/negative real return over the next 10+ years.

Skimming the top 10 holdings of each - I'd go with VDADX over VHYAX. Dividend appreciation, dividend aristocrats, usually good choices. Even taking a stock like AAPL for example - if you bought it in 2013, you'd have a 5% dividend yield on your original investment ($13/share back then, $0.60 dividend now). If you bought XOM in 2013 in the $80s, you'd only be making about 4% on your original investment. In terms of total return, again you'd be better off with AAPL by a long shot. So going for quality matters.

That kinda helps my point though. NKLA tanked but it has no correlation to the overall stock market, and the whole stock market went up in fact. Same with the entire SPAC bubble. Yes it was a bubble, but it popped and the market moved on its way without missing a beat. 

> The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

Even then the PE ratios are not the same. MSFT in it's peak in 1999 had a PE ratio of ~82, it now has a PE ratio of ~35. 

I'm not gonna say that *every* company today is fine. Many are not (including NKLA). But the 2000 was endemic throughout the market (i.e. say "internet" and stock 10x'd at ipo). Today the market is much more varied and plenty of companies trading at high multiples do so because they're growth is very real.

Sorta unrelated but I personally believe tech got an insane boost from covid which is/will be driving huge digitalization efforts and  accelerate growth for many saas/cloud centric companies.

author: matrixnsight
body:
Sort of. Anyone can make an android device. Only apple can make iOS devices. We saw how this played out in the PC space already - anyone could make a windows computer. 75% of the market now is Android. Apple is regaining small market share but it's just a cyclical oscillation that occurs due to all the other platforms dropping to zero in the last couple years. E.g. if 5% of Android users decide to give iPhone a try and 10% of iPhone users decide to switch to Android, iPhone still gains market share when it's far enough behind (so you get the feedback effect we see now).

The problem with closed platforms is they will eventually find themselves behind. There are just too many competitors - it's Apple vs. the world. Wearables, automotive, VR, AI capabilities... there are tons of ways the landscape is going to change in the next 10 years and it's highly likely Apple finds itself behind. Camera upgrades and poo emojis can only get you so far - eventually people don't need your new product.

Apple also charges a fee to develop apps. It's free on Android. On Android you can bypass the app store easily and download any app, even from a web address, on iOS it is a massive pain (we see this with fortnite).

Also we are at peak phones now - I only see downward pressure on margins due to the competition. Apple cannot get away with such high margins anymore - the only reason we don't see that (their margin is only slightly falling) is because they've added all these other high margin business to offset it (i.e. their services they've expanded in the last couple years). The reality is they're losing margin on their phones and they won't be able to hide that in their numbers forever (they certainly tried when they changed their reporting two years ago).

So those are my concerns with Apple. I always felt their original PE ratio was correct. Once Buffet got in on them they experienced PE expansion which is irrational IMO and I predict will correct itself at some point.

That's my opinion anyway. I think the market is really messed up right now based on bad speculation.

For reference, I'd say IBM, INTC, AAPL, and MSFT should be way closer in terms of PE than they actually are. Something more in line with reality would be IBM -> 10, INTC -> 14, AAPL -> 18, MSFT -> 22. MSFT and especially AAPL sitting at 30+ is just ridiculous, as is IBM hovering around 25. I don't think INTC is priced that unreasonably but it is compared to everything else right now.

> I have used both android and other OS's and I have found Apple to be the most easy for my work and personal life

This was true years ago. Not true anymore.

author: KingCuerv0
body:
Nothing too technical or a complex trading strategy but I have been working in Finance for over 15 years so I have a bit of experience.

Essentially I follow 20-30 stocks like a hawk, adding and removing stocks from this list. I know these companies in and out. Then I wait for a dislocation in the stock and or a sell off in the market. Once this happens I buy call LEAPs at least one to two years out, waiting for mean reversion and or whatever catalyst I believe takes place. Most importantly, I trim gains along the way up by setting specific targets. Thus at 20% gain I sell X amount of position, 50% x amount of position etc etc. This protects my gains even though does limit a bit of my upside but found this to be important in locking in gains before they all erode. Especially in options. IE earlier this year CEO of VWM left for INTC, VMW was crushed by over 15% for a stock that barely moves. That was an easy play knowing there was a dislocation and the stock soldoff based on their CEO leaving which really didn't matter since the company is essentially controlled by Dell. Then I bought calls on VMW, stock went back to previous levels and I trimmed at 40% and 70% initially then let the rest ride. Ended up closing my position a few weeks later for a bit over 60% gain in about 3 months by using target goals I set myself for each position and play.

Doesn't mean I am always invested all the time, I patiently wait for the right opportunities but do sit in higher cash position than most before striking. Currently 40% cash as markets are a bit frothy.

Have had excellent returns with this approach but it took time to develop and learn through my experiences.

body:
The AMD GPUs are heritage ATI and are not at the same level as NVidia. Yet. Also their drivers have been desperate for a long time. While NVidia sometimes puts their boot up their asshole wrt drivers, they generally just tickle the ring whereas AMD started with the booth firmly ensconced in the lower intestine and have been struggling to remove it. They have improved, but are still a ways behind.

Their CPUs are really good right now and Intel are floundering. That said they are still hampered because most current software isn't very good at multi threading so single core performance is important, especially for gaming, and Intel are competitive there. They are eating Intel in data centers though.

The big thing for me is that AMD have a runway - theyre still behind but have better CPUs and the data centre uptake is very bullish. Supply could become an issue here, because the big data centre players won't want to wait or to overpay. But assuming adequate supply there should be noticeable growth in the data center side, and of course GPU supply constraints mean that they will continue to sell as many as they make.

author: roald_1911
body: Maybe my prospects are longer term, or just wrong. But it seems to me that the x86 technology got itself into a corner and it would be very difficult to get out of there. AAPL proved that one can make a better processor starting from scratch, and if Windows will support ARM better, then the x86 market is toast. The RISC architecture has advantages over CISC architecture which we are observing right now and/or will observe in the near future. And these can't be undone, worked over, or something else. Every x86/x64 processor developed today can run programs written 30-40 years ago, while a company like Apple can come and say screw that, we start from scratch. This and other issues in the x86 architecture make it an (apparent at least) dead end. AMD is also offering a big competition to Intel, and in the server space there is also big competition. Most of us use phones or tablets with Arm processors. I would rather wait to see how the market progresses.

author: TheMagicHorsey
body:
I’m an Intel alumni too. But I worked with Gelsinger before he left Intel. Gelsinger is a way better CEO than anyone the company had between Grove and now. Intel has needed an engineering leader for a while and they’ve only had finance and sales guys.

You are counting out Intel based on their record of past failures over the last decade. However, my belief is that their execution and product line are going to improve drastically over the next couple years.

There’s room in the market for both TSM and Intel on the fab side. There’s a massive shortage in semiconductor capacity. Everything is going to need high performance chips in ten years. Current investments by TSM and Intel are just a drop in the ocean compared to what is needed to create capacity to meet future demand. So it’s not a zero sum market between TSM and Intel.

AMD vs Intel vs ARM is a bigger threat … however, people underestimate what Intel’s server group has cooking. Here also I think x86 with Intel cores will reign supreme for some high value work loads. Having said that, I think it’s unavoidable that ARM based VMs are going to swallow a lot of low end cloud compute. We tested AWS ARM VMs for many work loads and they were an absolute win on a cost adjusted basis. Intel will have to do some serious work to stop that drift.

Also, having my dev machine as an ARM Mac instead of an x86 MAc this year for the first time, means I’m actually running ARM server binaries natively and x86 binaries under emulation, instead of vice versa which was the case in previous years.

author: Protoculture_11
body:
the shortage issues massively massively hurt AMD. Without it, it would have shown higher YoY growth and faster marketshare growth in datacentre/HPC. Its fucked AMD a lot. We could have been 105 now instead of 95. TSMC expansion in the US along with Intels drive to expand into foundry leaves a lot of possibilities for AMD. Its not super clear that its a slam dunk win for AMD. Its more moving parts in the future whereas we prefer less moving parts with current competitive advantage.

NVDA is kicking AMD's ass inside out on GPU and hardware acceleration in datacentre/AI. We just have to accept it as it is. NVDA is something you should also look to get into when the price isnt so stupid. AMD is not NVDA though. Dont expect those price levels. NVDA has a fucking stranglehold in market sectors that AMD does not have.

AMD is however takings Intel's lunchmoney on x86 and its mainly because Intel fucked up on EUV. Intel's comments on "chiplets glued together"? Well those chiplets glued together are what allow AMD to make much better yields on smaller die sizes. When a wafer has an issue, you lose a lower portion of the wafer if you have smaller dies, or chiplets. So now AMD has several years lead on making chiplet designs talk to eachother faster or more efficiently.

Intel is however throwing in the towel and going to pay for EUV by TSMC in 2023. AMD has advance plans for 2023 with TSMC anyway and think they are second customer behind Apple so should be on a more even playing field moving forward in 2023, with the advantage of maybe 5 years with infinity fabric and chiplet design instead of monolithic dies. However if EUV pellicles come good by then, monolithic dies may be better - cant tell.

Trying to figure out short term moves with AMD is nuts. Just buy stock or leaps.

Everybody talking about designs…INTC ain’t behind in cpu or GPU design, they are behind in manufacturing capability and Fab expertise at the moment because they got skimpy on technical positions while financier bob was running the show at a vertically integrated company. Once they get as deep into EUV as tsmc and Samsung have been they’re vertical advantage will again become relevant. 

Once the fabs are a up and running they will take the market share back because tech innovation moves fast and amd can’t take advantage of Rsic-v or vertical integration the same way intel is right now..

Y’all are acting like intel and amd play on the same level lol, amd makes cpus and take margin cuts to prioritize their products at tsmc. This was their only advantage along with their underdog narrative . body:
In a margin account, buy an ATM LEAP call and sell an ATM LEAP put (same strikes). You can do this on the INTC Jan23 $55 for a small net credit. If you’ve got time to kill before the catalysts truly start pumping the stock you can still sell shorter term calls against it just like you would a covered call. Now you’ve got a synthetic covered call, which sounds incredibly fancy at your next party.

author: HillarysPornAccount
body:
LEAPs are a specific type of option (Long-Term Equity Anticipation) that expire more than 1 year out. Right now most LEAPs are for January 2023, and I think we'll see some January 2024s coming out in the next few months.

With the synthetic long, you should aim for as far out into the future as possible. This allows ample time for your investment thesis to play out (somewhat moot because you can roll indefinitely), and more importantly helps with taxes if you make gains on the long call (assuming USA here). No need to worry about the greeks in this strategy because the long call and short put offset the greeks on each other, but important to know your delta will come out to 1 after you buy the call and sell the put. Opening 1 of these positions with a delta of 1 means you are tracking the gains and losses of 100 shares. That's what gives this strategy the leverage it has, because you get a delta of 1 while sometimes getting paid to open the position.

Buying a call does not take care of the collateral for the written put and this strategy will use some of your available margin. Most securities will require 30ish% collateral for the short put, and higher for more volatile securities. So in this instance, entering at the 55 strikes for INTC will require $1,650 of margin, but you'll receive $.10 credit with yesterday's prices. Compare that to the cost to buy 100 shares, which is about $5,600 today, so this is where the leverage shows.

This has to be an unpopular opinion...and for the record, I distrust the CCP as much as the next person, but these crackdowns may not be entirely bad. Let's look at some examples:

\- So in this case, Didi's operation got suspended because "Didi had illegally collected users' personal data."

\- Alibaba got fined because of monopolistic practices.

\- Ant Group's IPO got slashed because the CCP wanted to regulate Ant Group like an actual bank.

Microsoft has been fined millions by the EU for monopolistic practices as well. But everyone loves Microsoft stocks nonetheless.

$NET is on a fundamental basis is over valued. They expect rev to be $500M+ this year but they trade at $33B. It’s been on of my biggest picked winners. 

Here is a quick breakdown of what the popular services they offer, highly scaleable and a HUGE TAM.

https://www.freelancer.com/articles/web-development/cloudflare

However I sold off at $75, $85 levels due to price action getting ahead of the fundamental business. I’ve exited about 50% of my position. I still have 200 shares because I believe, it could do some long term stuff well and be a $100B company. But I can’t allocate so much of my portfolio in this company vs a FB/AMZN/GOOG (where I get growth, balance sheet safety, and moat)

From here, if you want to get in on the action. You have to believe they do a few things…
1) surprise HEAVILY on revenue growth and forward guidance
2) grow more into their cyber security suite of tools beyond just basic stuff like their widely used DDOS prevention (a ton of websites use them for this) and firewall 
3) Content delivery network investment trend continues and profit margins aren’t competed away with bigger boys entering the game (ie GOOG, MSFT, AMZN)
4) website speeds overwhelmingly determine ranking on google and mobile searches

Cloudflare and Fastly are the two more popular services for websites and apps to use as they offer ease of use to speed up website access for users and support to prevent website downtime. Folks have frequently complimented on how easy cloudflare is to use.

With AAPL, same theory, if you invested $1000, you're currently at $1500, so sell $500 worth to return to your original capital investement.

&#x200B;

Whatever you do with that $ better out-perform MSFT or AAPL, otherwise, just leave it there.

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
ELI5: 

- Burry believes (as he wrote): "passive investing has removed price discovery from the equity markets". https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-04/michael-burry-explains-why-index-funds-are-like-subprime-cdos

- price discovery is the process of estimating a reasonable fair value for a stock. 

- because relatively few people are buying/selling stocks based on their fair value, prices for stocks are often being determined mainly by cash-flows. see Tesla or dogecoin for examples. Tesla sells under 1% all vehicles worldwide but is somehow worth *more than all the other carmakers combined* because lots of people were buying Tesla stock and not because of any financial status of Tesla. dogecoin started LITERALLY as a joke but somehow was more valuable than companies like Ford Motors only because a ton of cash flowed into Dogecoin. this is all sheer insanity by traditional stock valuation guidelines. asset bubbles are nothing new, but Burry believes it's being exacerbated by passive investing. 

- Burry believes this situation of prices being based on cash flows is similar to what happened in the housing bubble, when multi-zillion Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDOs) were being priced not by a reasonable estimate of their fair value but by cash-flows. 

- when flows reverse and lots of people want out of index funds, it will get ugly because so many stocks are linked/benchmarked to major stock indexes *including lower volume stocks*. consider VTI: the top holdings (Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson) might have a billion shares in total and hundreds of millions of dollars trading each day. but the smallest company stocks might have only a few million shares and a few million dollars trading each day. if too many people want to sell all at the same time, it will drive prices down sharply because these stocks are so often sold as a bundle/unit. as Burry puts it: "The theater keeps getting more crowded, but the exit door is the same as it always was"

>since the guy predicted 2007-2008 crash.

he also predicted the dot-com bubble.

author: zxc123zxc123
body:
Hi. I'm from the Intel side! I think AMD side shouldn't worry too much about INTC. It's a big old ship that's getting bombarded from all sides. The fact that it's a big ship means it's changes will take time. I'm giving Gelsinger a chance to right the ship, but it will take a long while to undo BSwan's bad moves, get the right people, develop the chips, and catch up to AMD. 

A plus side for everyone is that the semi-space is a growing area with electronification, digitization, and "5G-cloudification" of everything along with the increasing importance of AI & tech in business and government. Semis are so important in fact, that at this point US Gov should really be looking at INTC/NVD/TI more like they did Ford/GM 100 years ago: as a strategic industrial/military resource. 

Real threat to AMD isn't INTC. INTC was the big market share holder in the past and isn't likely gaining any ground any time soon. What AMD and all the trad chip manufacturers should fear is FAAAM & BAT. Apple has started designing it's own chips. They aren't going back to using outsourced chips. If history says anything it's that Apple will continue to cut others out as they continue to in-house their chips for their entire lineup while improving their chips just like how they kept improving their computers, just like how the iphone kept improving until NOK/MOT were beat, just like how a good chunk of the watch market is Apple watches, just like how Ipads have taken away from of the laptop space, just like how Apple TV keeps chipping away at cable, just like how the app store and Apple's eco system keeps growing, etcetcetc. There is nothing AMD/NVD/INTC can do to stop Apple. And Apple is just the first. MSFT also doing the same. Google, Facebook, and Amazon might follow suit. China's Tencent and Alibaba will likely copy what the US companies do as soon as Pooh Bear gets done man handling them.

author: YourInnate
body:
It's a matter of perspective and big picture stuff. If you bough a SPY leap the day before the market crashed last year from covid, and bought 100 shares the day before the crash in covid, the LEAP would be worth more today.

2-5% a month seems super low, but options are a grind. When in doubt, zoom out. 2-5% a month is 25-60% a year. Consider the indexes historically return 10%, doubling that on your bad years and quintupling it on your good years seems like a good trade.

Another note, this past year has been a historic bull run/recovery for most of the stock market. You can't compare throwing money into microsoft or google and watching it appreciate vs selling options on the same underlying. Likewise, if you had been selling RIOT/MARA puts the first 4 months of the year, you could've been making 10% a week. 

Everything in the market is perspective. If you think 2-5% a month is too slow/boring... You might consider roulette.
